Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Combined Ion Exchange as a Pre- and Post-Treatment for High Pressure Membrane Systems

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of membrane systems in water treatment has been limited by the fouling that occurs in the system, which increases the operating costs and decreases the usable life of the membranes.

Previous research has shown that two major foulants of membrane systems are organic matter and divalent cations, specifically calcium. Traditional treatment processes that remove these constituents have limitations. Combined ion exchange treatment, which uses a mixture of anion and cation exchange resins, has been shown to effectively remove organic matter and calcium from raw waters6. However, using combined ion exchange as a pre-treatment for membrane systems has not been explored. The objective of this work was to determine if treating raw water with combined ion exchange prior to membrane filtration would alleviate membrane fouling.

Two types of organic matter that are commercially available were used to make synthetic waters. One type of organic matter, Aldrich humic acid, has been extensively used in membrane fouling experiments although it is not from an aquatic source and therefore might have different properties than the organic matter in drinking water. The other type, IHSS natural organic matter, is from an aquatic source, but is significantly more expensive. Both organic matter types were used to determine if there was a difference in removal and fouling in the ion exchange and membrane filtration processes.

The results of the experiment showed that the two types of organic matter did foul the membrane differently before the use of pre-treatment, had different removal efficiencies when using the combined ion exchange pre-treatment, and that the pre-treatment changed the magnitudes of fouling in subsequent membrane filtration (i.e. the reduction in fouling was different for the two synthetic waters). These observations are important because the research that has been done using commercially available organic matter to make synthetic waters could be irrelevant for treating natural waters. These findings were shared with the scientific community at the American Water Works Association’s Membrane Technology Conference in March 2011.
